node.title: A Monument to the Lives of Black Women and Girls
node.alt: “The Black Girlhood Altar,” a temporary monument, was assembled to honor the lives of Black girls cut short by violence.
node.description: “The Black Girlhood Altar” began as a community project fueled by collective grief. Now it’s on display at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago.
node.content: ["CHICAGO \u2014 The Friday before Thanksgiving, as millions of people around the country started packing up cars and prepared to board flights to reunite with their families, about 20 guests gathered inside a quiet gallery at the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago for a moment of collective mourning.", "Toward the back of the room were two large wooden altars, with steps adorned with offerings meant to honor the lives of Black girls: satin hair bonnets, nail polish, a baby doll, children\u2019s books. A video of a 16-year-old girl doing her bouncy hair on TikTok played on a loop. Candles, teddy bears and bouquets of flowers were placed throughout the display.", "Together that evening were friends, family and supporters of Breonna Taylor, Latasha Harlins, Marcie Gerald, Lyniah Bell, Rekia Boyd and Ma\u2019Khia Bryant (the star of that looping TikTok video, who was fatally shot by police in Columbus, Ohio, in April). Over the last several years, their names had become rallying cries in their communities \u2014 some far beyond \u2014 after their lives were cut short by violence.", "\u201cThe Black Girlhood Altar,\u201d a temporary monument that had traveled through various neighborhoods in Chicago before landing at the MCA as part of an exhibition of work by the artist Andrea Powers, was meant to honor them and the countless other Black women and girls whose deaths preceded the national reckoning that followed the murder of George Floyd in May 2020. Most of their lives had never been memorialized on such a grand scale.", "\u201cIt\u2019s taking trauma and reclaiming it for yourself and honoring the people in it,\u201d said Scheherazade Tillet, a founder of A Long Walk Home, the national organization that sponsored the creation of the temporary monument. \u201cThe horror is in the trauma, and the beauty is in the spirit of the person.\u201d", "The altar was assembled by the artists Leah Gipson and Robert Narciso, Black girls from the Chicago community, and Ms. Tillet. (Her sister and co-founder, Salamishah Tillet, is a contributing critic for The New York Times.)", "In recent years, there has been a global push to remove statues and monuments of racist historical figures. At the same time, some artists have been galvanized to honor people from marginalized groups, including Kehinde Wiley, through his \u201cRumors of War\u201d series, and a recent public art exhibition in New York City showcasing bronze busts of African-American figures.", "Sarah Elizabeth Lewis, an art historian and professor at Harvard University, said the commissioning of these statues as historical monuments are taken down signals \u201can expansion in the American narrative.\u201d", "\u201cThese new monuments signify that we\u2019ve underestimated how rights and representation in U.S. democracy are tied to the work of visual representation,\u201d Dr. Lewis wrote in an email, \u201cwhich includes the signaling power of monuments in the public sphere.\u201d", "\u201cWe are in the midst of a profound reckoning about the true marriage of race, rights and visual representation for the broader work of justice,\u201d she added.", "In the gallery that chilly November night, the significance of a monument to the lives of Black girls was not lost on the guests. Juniyah Palmer, Ms. Taylor\u2019s sister, did a lap around the room, then stepped outside to take a moment to herself. Evelyn Hightower lingered on the image of Lyniah Bell, her daughter, hanging from one of seven pendants on an adjacent wall dedicated to seven victims.", "Kenneth Walker, Ms. Taylor\u2019s boyfriend, said he felt moved by the display. \u201cJust everybody\u2019s vibe and mutual pain about all these different situations,\u201d he said through a face mask with \u201cBreonna Taylor\u201d printed across the front. \u201cYou can definitely tell people really care all over the world.\u201d", "The evening before, the group had gathered for a private, family-style dinner at Taste 222, a restaurant in Chicago\u2019s Fulton River District, along with youth members from A Long Walk Home, known as the Girl/Friends. Chandeliers and dimly lit candles illuminated the room as people took their seats at two long tables.", "\u201cI think this dinner is about love,\u201d Ms. Tillet said. \u201cThese are the people to remember. These are the people we need to care for and to immerse them with these young people who are the legacy. Who have been marching for them.\u201d", "After opening remarks, a first course of kale salad with cranberries and sunflower seeds was served. There were notes of levity in what might have otherwise been a solemn gathering, as guests became acquainted with the space and the menu.", "\u201cI like salad with good ranch,\u201d Mr. Walker said with a smile.", "\u201cYou don\u2019t even like kale,\u201d Ms. Palmer retorted.", "The evening had been billed as a night of connection and healing for the survivors, but for the most part they sat in pods, holding their unique, unspeakable losses close.", "Elizabeth Gerald, whose 15-year-old daughter, Marcie, died by suicide in 2015 after being abducted and sexually assaulted, said that when she first started meeting with other mothers years ago in Chicago who could relate to her tragedy, she was taken aback by the divisions felt between survivors whose loved ones lacked name recognition and those whose stories had become the subjects of national news and protests.", "\u201cHigh-profile is like Trayvon and Sandra Bland, and Breonna Taylor is considered high-profile because of the media,\u201d Ms. Gerald said. \u201cBut the low-profile are like the mothers who lose to police shootings that nobody knows about.\u201d", "\u201cI think a lot of times it\u2019s jealousy because they\u2019re feeling like, \u2018Well, what about me?\u2019\u201d Ms. Gerald continued. \u201cIt feels really good to be able to have something more small, intimate. Just us and the families helping each other, being there for each other.\u201d", "After dessert, the hosts took a moment to explain the history of the altar and its intention. Gift bags were handed to families, and each group was presented with custom beaded bracelets and lockets dedicated to their loved ones.", "\u201cAw, it\u2019s Breonna,\u201d said an emotional Mr. Walker as he opened the locket to find a picture of his girlfriend. \u201cThis is really nice.\u201d", "At the end of the night, a microphone was passed around the room so that each attendee could share a wish for Black women. Their words echoed through the room like a benediction: \u201cProtection.\u201d \u201cFreedom.\u201d \u201cJustice.\u201d \u201cJoy.\u201d"]
